summary:
The case concerns three applications against the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, alleging violations of Article 3, Article 8, and Article 13 of the European Convention on Human Rights. The applicants, three women, were stateless or citizens of foreign countries, married to British citizens, and were denied British citizenship and subsequently deported from the United Kingdom. They claimed that their rights under Article 8 (right to respect for private and family life) and Article 14 (prohibition of discrimination) were violated due to the denial of British citizenship and the subsequent deportation.

The applicants argued that the UK government's policy of denying British citizenship to foreign-born wives of British citizens and subsequently deporting them was discriminatory and violated their rights under Article 8 and Article 14. They also argued that the policy was in violation of Article 3, as it led to the separation of families and caused them significant distress.

The Court held that the refusal of permission to remain with the applicants' husbands was discriminatory and violated their rights under Article 8 and Article 14. The Court also held that there was no effective domestic remedy available to the applicants, in violation of Article 13.

The case highlights the importance of ensuring that immigration and asylum decisions are made in a fair and non-discriminatory manner, and that individuals who are affected by these decisions have access to effective domestic remedies.
